sen.j: 荘園公領制（しょうえんこうりょうせい）とは、日本の中世日本における、荘園と公領を土台とした、重層的土地支配構造のことである。
sen.e: The Shoen-Koryo system is a multilayered land governance structure which is grounded in minors (shoen) and lands under the control of the feudal government (koryo) in medieval times in Japan.
The Shoen-Koryo system was a multilayered land governance structure which was grounded in manors (shoen) and lands under the control of the feudal government (koryo) in medieval times in Japan.
The Shoen-Koryo system was a multilayered land governance structure which was grounded in shoen (manors) and lands under the control of the koryo (feudal government) in medieval times in Japan.

sen.j: 歴史学者の網野善彦が提唱した。
sen.e: The concept for the Shoen-Koryo system was proposed by the historian, Yoshihiko AMINO.
The concept for the Shoen-Koryo system was proposed by the historian, Yoshihiko AMINO.
The concept for the Shoen-Koryo system was proposed by the historian, Yoshihiko AMINO.

sen.j: 11世紀中後期から12世紀初期にかけて成立し、院政期を通じて発展し、鎌倉時代前後に最盛期を迎えた。
sen.e: The Shoen-Koryo system was established from the mid and late 11th century through until the early 12th century, developed through the period of the Cloister government, and peaked around the Kamakura Period.

The Shoen-Koryo system was established in the mid to late 11th century and continued through until the early 12th century, so it was developed through the period of the Cloister government, and peaked around the Kamakura Period.

The Shoen-Koryo system was established in the mid to late 11th century and continued through until the early 12th century, so it was developed through the period of the Cloister government, and peaked around the Kamakura period.

sen.j: その一方で、鎌倉時代には地頭による侵食を受け、室町時代には守護（守護大名）によって蚕食されるなど、武士の進出に伴って次第に解体への道を進み、戦国時代 (日本)頃までにほぼ形骸化した。
sen.e: The system, however, was encroached on by Jito (lords of the manors) in the Kamakura Period and by the provincial constable (Shugo Daimyos) in the Muromachi Period, and thus gradually headed for dismantlement in accordance with the rise of samurais and almost became a dead letter by the time of the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States) (Japan).

The system, however, was encroached on by Jito (lords of the manors) in the Kamakura Period and by provincial constables (Shugo Daimyos) in the Muromachi Period, and thus gradually dismantled in accordance with the rise of samurais and almost became a mere formality by the time of the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States) (Japan).

The system, however, was encroached on by Jito (lords of the manors) in the Kamakura period and by Shugo Daimyos (provincial constables) in the Muromachi period, and thus gradually dismantled in accordance with the rise of samurais and almost became a mere formality by the time of the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States) (Japan).
sen.cmt: スペル英語説明位置移動

sen.j: 最終的には太閤検地で完全に消滅する。
sen.e: It completely disappeared as Taiko kenchi (cadastral surveys conducted by Hideyoshi) was carried out.
It completely disappeared as Taiko kenchi (cadastral surveys conducted by Hideyoshi) was carried out.
It completely disappeared as Taiko kenchi (cadastral surveys conducted by Hideyoshi) was carried out.

sen.j: なお、この項目においての荘園・公領とは、それぞれ荘園公領制の土台となった寄進地系荘園・国衙領を指すものとする。
sen.e: Note that minors (shoen) and lands under the control of the feudal government (koryo) described here mean kishinchi-kei-shoen and Kokugaryo (provincial lands), which became the base of the Shoen-Koryo system.

Note that the manors (shoen) and lands under the control of the feudal government (koryo) described here mean kishinchi-kei-shoen and Kokugaryo (provincial lands), which became the base of the Shoen-Koryo system.
Note that the shoen and lands under the control of the koryo described here mean kishinchi-kei-shoen and Kokugaryo (provincial lands), which became the base of the Shoen-Koryo system.
sen.cmt: 英語説明)既出のため削除

sen.j: 平安時代中期以降、開発領主による墾田開発が盛んになる。
sen.e: After the mid Heian Period, new rice fields were actively developed by Kaihatsu-ryoshu.
After the mid Heian Period, new rice fields were actively developed by Kaihatsu-ryoshu.
After the mid Heian Period, new rice fields were actively developed by Kaihatsu-ryoshu.

sen.j: 彼らは国衙から田地の私有が認められたが、その権利は危ういものであった。
sen.e: Although Kokuga (provincial offices) allowed them to have their own private lands, the right was very fragile.
Although Kokuga (provincial offices) allowed them to have their own private lands, the right was very fragile.
Although Kokuga (provincial offices) allowed them to have their own private lands, the right was very fragile.

sen.j: そこで、彼らはその土地を荘園として受領層に寄進することとなる。
sen.e: Accordingly, they donated the lands to the Juryoso (career provincial official class) as shoen.
Accordingly, they donated the lands to the Juryoso (career provincial official class) as shoen.
Accordingly, they donated the lands to the Juryoso (career provincial official class) as shoen.

sen.j: 受領層は彼ら田堵（＝開発領主）を荘官に任命し、その土地の実効支配権を認める代わりに、荘官から一定の税収を受け取る。
sen.e: The Juryoso (career provincial official class) assigned those Tato (cultivators) (=Kaihatsu-ryoshu) to Shokan (general term for a variety of shoen (manor) officials responsible for the management and assignment of duties, tax collection, and protection of shoen) and collected certain tax revenues from the Shokan in exchange for recognizing their effective authorities for the lands.

The Juryoso (career provincial official class) assigned the Tato (cultivators) (=Kaihatsu-ryoshu) to Shokan (a general term for a variety of shoen (manor) officials responsible for the management and assignment of duties, tax collection, and protection of shoen) and collected certain tax revenues from the Shokan in exchange for recognizing their effective authorities for the lands.

The Juryoso (career provincial official class) assigned the Tato (cultivators) (=Kaihatsu-ryoshu) to Shokan (a general term for a variety of shoen (manor) officials responsible for the management and assignment of duties, tax collection, and protection of shoen) and collected certain tax revenues from the Shokan in exchange for recognizing their effective authorities for the lands.

sen.j: こうして荘園を持つようになった受領層を領家と呼ぶ。
sen.e: The Juryoso who obtained Shoen in this way were called Ryoke (main proprietors).
The Juryoso who obtained shoen in this way were called Ryoke (main proprietors).
The Juryoso who obtained shoen in this way were called Ryoke (main proprietors).

sen.j: 領家は次第に、国衙領を支配するようになった同階層の国司との対立を増すようになる。
sen.e: The Ryoke gradually became in opposition to the Kokushi (provincial governors) in the same class, who were governing the kokuga lands.
The Ryoke gradually became rivals of the Kokushi (provincial governors) in the same class, who were governing the kokuga lands.
The Ryoke gradually became rivals of the Kokushi (provincial governors) in the same class, who were governing the kokuga lands.

sen.j: そこで彼らは自らの荘園をさらに権門層に寄進し、保護を求める代わりに一定の税収を納めた。
sen.e: Hence, they donated their own lands to the Kenmonso (gateway-of-power class) and paid certain tax revenues to have them protect the lands.
Hence, they donated their own lands to the Kenmonso (gateway-of-power class) and paid certain tax revenues to have them protect the lands.
Hence, they donated their own lands to the Kenmonso (gateway-of-power class) and paid certain tax revenues to have them protect the lands.

sen.j: こうして荘園を集積した権門層を本家と呼ぶ。
sen.e: The Kenmonso who collected shoen were called Honke (protectors).
The Kenmonso who collected shoen were called Honke (protectors).
The Kenmonso who collected shoen were called Honke (protectors).

sen.j: 時を同じくして、律令制の崩壊と共に、上級貴族は政治への意欲を全くなくし、地方政治は国司に一任されていた。
sen.e: Coincidentally, with the demise of the Ritsuryo system (the political system based on the ritsuryo codes), the high-level aristocrats lost their eagerness for politics completely, and accordingly, the local politics was entrusted to the Kokushi.

Coincidentally, with the demise of the Ritsuryo system (the political system based on the ritsuryo codes), the high-level aristocrats lost their eagerness for politics completely, and accordingly, local politics were entrusted to the Kokushi.

Coincidentally, with the demise of the Ritsuryo system (the political system based on the ritsuryo codes), the high-level aristocrats lost their eagerness for politics completely, and accordingly, local politics were entrusted to the Kokushi.

sen.j: 増え続ける荘園に対抗して、国司は大名田堵を在庁官人に任命し、自らの手元に置き、さらには惣司・郷司・保司として、地方行政官とした。
sen.e: As competition with ever-increasing shoen, Kokushi assigned Daimyo tato (daimyo cultivator) to Zaicho kanjin (resident public officials) and deployed them on hand; moreover, they had Soji, Goji, and Hoji (all of which were a local government official under the ritsuryo system) as local government officials.

In competition with the ever-increasing shoen, the Kokushi assigned Daimyo tato (daimyo cultivators) to Zaicho kanjin (resident public officials) and deployed them on hand; moreover, they had Soji, Goji, and Hoji (all of which were local government officials under the ritsuryo system) appointed as local government officials.

In competition with the ever-increasing shoen, the Kokushi assigned Daimyo tato (daimyo cultivators) to Zaicho kanjin (resident public officials) and deployed them on hand; moreover, they had Soji, Goji, and Hoji (all of which were local government officials under the ritsuryo system) appointed as local government officials.

sen.j: 惣司・郷司・保司はそれぞれ一定額をそれぞれ国司、朝廷に納めればよい。
sen.e: Soji, Goji, and Hoji were supposed to pay a certain amount of tax revenues to each of the Kokushi and the imperial court.
Soji, Goji, and Hoji were supposed to pay a certain amount of tax revenues to each of the Kokushi and the imperial court.
Soji, Goji, and Hoji were supposed to pay a certain amount of tax revenues to each of the Kokushi and the imperial court.

sen.j: その後、荘園の更なる増大で税収が減り、上級貴族に俸給を払えなくなった朝廷は、彼らに知行国として国を与え、その国に関する国司の任命権と税収を上級貴族に与えた。
sen.e: After that, the imperial court, who were no longer able to pay salary to the high-level aristocrats due to decreased tax revenues because of the growing number of shoen, gave territories as Chigyo koku (proprietary provinces), as well as the patronage of the Kokushi and tax revenues regarding the province, to the high-level aristocrats.

After that, the imperial court, who were no longer able to pay the salaries of the high-level aristocrats due to decreased tax revenues because of the growing number of shoen, gave territories as Chigyo koku (proprietary provinces), as well as the patronage of the Kokushi and tax revenues regarding the province, to the high-level aristocrats.

After that, the imperial court, who were no longer able to pay the salaries of the high-level aristocrats due to decreased tax revenues because of the growing number of shoen, gave territories as Chigyo koku (proprietary provinces), as well as the patronage of the Kokushi and tax revenues regarding the province, to the high-level aristocrats.

sen.j: 同様に皇族にも院宮分国制が敷かれ、こうして権門層たる上級貴族、受領層たる国司、大名田堵たる惣司・郷司・保司が結びつき、荘園制とほとんど変わらぬ構造となった。
sen.e: In the same manner, the Ingu bunkoku sei (provincial allotment system) was applied to the high-level aristocrats, which formed a structure in which the high-level aristocrats as Kenmonso, the Kokushi as Juryoso and the Soji, Goji, and Hoji as Daimyo tato were connected, resulting in the unchanged system from the Shoen system.

In the same manner, the Ingu bunkoku sei (provincial allotment system) was applied to the high-level aristocrats, it formed a structure in which the high-level aristocrats were connected as Kenmonso, the Kokushi as Juryoso, and the Soji, Goji, and Hoji as Daimyo tato, resulting in as system which was little different from the Shoen system.

In the same manner, the Ingu bunkoku sei (provincial allotment system) was applied to the high-level aristocrats, it formed a structure in which the high-level aristocrats were connected as Kenmonso, the Kokushi as Juryoso, and the Soji, Goji, and Hoji as Daimyo tato, resulting in as system which was little different from the Shoen system.

sen.j: なお、この重層的支配構造は「職の体系」とも呼ばれ、それぞれの立場の職務と権限を「～職」と呼んだ。
sen.e: This multilayered governance structure was also called "Shiki system" and each job title and authority were referred as "XXX shiki."
This multilayered governance structure was also called the "Shiki system" and each job title and authority was referred as "XXX shiki".
This multilayered governance structure was also called the "Shiki system" and each job title and authority was referred as "XXX shiki."

sen.j: （領家職、惣司職、郷司職など）
sen.e: (e.g. Ryoke shiki, Soji shiki, Goshi shiki, etc.)
(e.g. Ryoke shiki, Soji shiki, Goshi shiki, etc.)
(e.g. Ryoke shiki, Soji shiki, Goshi shiki, etc.)

sen.j: 変遷・衰退
sen.e: Transition and decline
Transition and decline
Transition and decline

sen.j: 次第に在地領主同士の土地争いが増えるに従って、彼らは武装し、武士となった。
sen.e: As disputes of land increased among the Ryoshu (feudal lords) of the provinces, they armed themselves and eventually became samurais.
As disputes over land increased among the Ryoshu (feudal lords) of the provinces, they armed themselves and eventually became samurais.
As disputes over land increased among the Ryoshu (feudal lords) of the provinces, they armed themselves and eventually became samurais.

sen.j: 鎌倉幕府の成立に従い、主に東国の武士は鎌倉幕府に奉公する、御家人となった。
sen.e: With the establishment of the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), samurais, especially in Kanto region, became Gokenin (lower-ranking vassals in the Kamakura and Edo periods) who entered into service for the Kamakura bakufu.

With the establishment of the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), samurais, especially in the Kanto region, became Gokenin (lower-ranking vassals in the Kamakura and Edo periods) who entered into the service of the Kamakura bakufu.

With the establishment of the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), samurais, especially in the Kanto region, became Gokenin (lower-ranking vassals in the Kamakura and Edo periods) who entered into the service of the Kamakura bakufu.

sen.j: 彼らはその代償たる御恩として、地頭に補任され、所領の支配権が鎌倉幕府に保証された。
sen.e: As benefits of the position, they were designated as Jito and the authority of their lands was guaranteed.
As benefits of the position, they were designated as Jito and the authority of their lands was guaranteed.
As benefits of the position, they were designated as Jito and the authority of their lands was guaranteed.

sen.j: 彼らは地頭という全く新しい職に付いたわけではなく、あくまで荘官や郷司・保司のうち幕府と主従関係を結んだものが地頭と呼ばれる点に付いては注意されたい。
sen.e: Note that it does not mean that they took up a completely new Shiki called Jito; Jito was simply a position, among Shokan, Goji and Hoji, which had a master-subordinate relationship with the feudal government.

Note that it does not mean that they took up a completely new Shiki called Jito; Jito was simply a position, among Shokan, Goji and Hoji, which had a master-subordinate relationship with the feudal government.

Note that it does not mean that they took up a completely new Shiki called Jito; Jito was simply a position, among Shokan, Goji and Hoji, which had a master-subordinate relationship with the feudal government.

sen.j: 当然彼らは荘官や郷司・保司以上の職は持たないのである。
sen.e: They, of course, did not have a Shiki which was higher than Shokan, Goji or Hoji.
They, of course, did not have a Shiki which was higher than Shokan, Goji or Hoji.
They, of course, did not have a Shiki which was higher than Shokan, Goji or Hoji.

sen.j: 関東御成敗地に関しては幕府が地頭の補任権を持つ。
sen.e: The feudal government had the authority to assign Jito in Kanto goseibaichi.
sen.cmt: 用語集にある英語の説明をそのまま「Kanto goseibaichi」の後に付けるべきかどうか判断できなかったため、付けずに「Kanto goseibaichi」のみと致しました。
sen.e: The feudal government had the authority to assign Jito in Kanto goseibaichi.

The feudal government had the authority to assign Jito in Kanto goseibaichi (provinces, manors and provincial lands where the shogun families of Kamakura bakufu possess the power to appoint/dismiss Jito).
sen.cmt: 関東御成敗地の訳を追加しました。

sen.j: つまり、その内関東進止領・関東御口入地には鎌倉幕府とは異なる荘園領主・国司が存在し、しかも彼らは荘官や郷司・保司の任命権は持たないのである。
sen.e: In other words, Kanto shinshiryo and Kando gokunyuuchi had Shoen-ryoshu and Kokushi who are different from those of the Kamakura bakufu and had no patronage of Shokan, Goji and Hoji.
sen.cmt: 用語集にある英語の説明をそのまま「Kanto shinshiryo」と「Kando gokunyuuchi」の後に付けるべきかどうか判断できなかったため、付けずに「Kanto shinshiryo」と「Kando gokunyuuchi」のみと致しました。
sen.e: In other words, the Kanto shinshiryo and Kando gokunyuuchi had Shoen-ryoshu and Kokushi who were different from those of the Kamakura bakufu and had no patronage of Shokan, Goji, or Hoji.

In other words, the Kanto shinshiryo (manors and provincial lands where the shogun of the Kamakura bakufu has the right to appoint/dismiss Jito) and Kanto gokunyuchi (manors and provincial lands where the shogun of the Kamakura bakufu has the right to recommend Jito) had Shoen-ryoshu and Kokushi who were different from those of the Kamakura bakufu and had no patronage of Shokan, Goji, or Hoji.
sen.cmt: 関東進止領・関東御口入地の説明を補足しました。

sen.j: ただ頼朝の頃から、守護が在庁官人を指揮して大田文（土地台帳）を作成していた。
sen.e: It is notable that the provincial constables had Zaicho kanjin (the local district officials) prepare Ota bumi (cadasters) from the time of Yoritomo.
It is notable that the provincial constables had Zaicho kanjin (local district officials) prepare Ota bumi (land ledgers) from the time of Yoritomo.
It is notable that the provincial constables had Zaicho kanjin (local district officials) prepare Ota bumi (land ledgers) from the time of Yoritomo.

sen.j: そこで、地頭の年貢の滞納や領民の不法使用など、地頭職を越えた越権行為が行われるようになり、荘園領主や国司との間に紛争が生じた。
sen.e: Jito's acts beyond their authorities, including arrears in taxes and illegal use of the people in the province, gave rise to a dispute with the Shoen-ryoshu and the Kokushi.
Jito's acts beyond their authorities, including arrears in taxes and illegal use of the people in the province, gave rise to disputes with the Shoen-ryoshu and the Kokushi.
Jito's acts beyond their authorities, including arrears in taxes and illegal use of the people in the province, gave rise to disputes with the Shoen-ryoshu and the Kokushi.

sen.j: その解決策が地頭請や下地中分である。
sen.e: As solutions for this issue, Jito uke (proprietor's annual tax) and Shitaji chubun (physical division of the land) were adopted.
To resolve this issue, the Jito uke (proprietor's annual tax) and Shitaji chubun (physical division of land) were adopted.
To resolve this issue, the Jito uke (proprietor's annual tax) and Shitaji chubun (physical division of land) were adopted.

sen.j: このようにして地頭は領地の支配権を強めていった。
sen.e: In this way, Jito strengthened the control of the territories gradually.
In this way, the Jito gradually strengthened their control of the territories.
In this way, the Jito gradually strengthened their control of the territories.

sen.j: 室町時代になると、室町幕府の設立の経緯から、守護の権力が強大であった。
sen.e: From the start of the Muromachi Period, provincial constables enlarged their power based on the background of the establishment of the Muromachi bakufu.
From the start of the Muromachi Period, provincial constables increased their power based on the background of the establishment of the Muromachi bakufu.
From the start of the Muromachi period, provincial constables increased their power based on the background of the establishment of the Muromachi bakufu.

sen.j: 彼らは守護領国制の成立を目指して、在庁官人を含む鎌倉期の地頭、国人を被官化し、国衙や彼らの所持していた領地を掌握した。
sen.e: Aiming at the establishment of Shugo-ryogokusei, they relegated Jito and Kokujin, including Zaicho-kanjin, in the Kamakura Period to their subordinates and took over Kokuga and their lands.
With the aim of establishing the Shugo-ryogokusei in the Kamakura Period, they relegated Jito and Kokujin, including Zaicho-kanjin, to their subordinates and took over the Kokuga and their lands.
With the aim of establishing the Shugo-ryogokusei, they relegated Jito and Kokujin, including Zaicho-kanjin of the Kamakura period, to their subordinates and took over the Kokuga and their lands.
sen.cmt: in the Kamakura period位置移動

sen.j: それと前後して、守護は半済、守護請等で、荘園領主等の権利をも侵食して行き、戦国時代 (日本)になると、守護大名に代わった戦国大名はさらに土地の一円知行を進めていく。
sen.e: Around the same time, provincial constables also encroached on the other rights including the power of Shoen-ryoshu using the systems of Hanzei and Shugo-uke, and from the start of the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States) (Japan), Daimyo (Japanese territorial lords) in the Sengoku Period who turned into Shugo Daimyo further promoted Ichien chigyo (complete proprietorships) of the lands.

Around the same time, provincial constables also encroached on other rights, including the power of Shoen-ryoshu using the systems of Hanzei and Shugo-uke, and from the start of the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States) (Japan), Daimyo (Japanese territorial lords) in the Sengoku Period who turned into Shugo Daimyo further promoted Ichien chigyo (complete proprietorship) of the lands.

Around the same time, provincial constables also encroached on other rights, including the power of Shoen-ryoshu using the systems of Hanzei and Shugo-uke, and from the start of the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States) (Japan), Daimyo (Japanese territorial lords) in the Sengoku Period who turned into Shugo Daimyo further promoted Ichien chigyo (complete proprietorship) of the lands.

sen.j: その後、太閤検地により、土地には直接の耕作者の権利しか認められなくなり、以前までの重層的支配構造は名実共に解消された。
sen.e: After that, based on the Taiko kenchi, only new cultivator's right became effective, resulting in disappearance of the old multilayered land governance structure in reality and in name.
After that, based on the Taiko kenchi, only new cultivator's rights became effective, resulting in the disappearance of the old multilayered land governance structure in both reality and in name.
After that, based on the Taiko kenchi, only new cultivator's rights became effective, resulting in the disappearance of the old multilayered land governance structure in both reality and in name.
